article: Do you remember last summer, when angry travelers were urging the government to do something about airline customer service? Airlines _ to improve, and they adopted new standards just before Christmas. _ as another summer nears, plenty of _ travelers don't see much improvement in customer _ overall. This month, the Department of Transportation's (DOT) office will publish its first critical _ on whether airlines are _ their promises. One survey suggests problems: the number of _ to the DOT about the top 10 airlines in the first _ rose 89% from a year ago . Hit last summer by passenger complaints and the threat of consumer-protection laws by the _ , 14 airlines _ to adopt a set of basic customer-service standards called Customers First . The "12 promises" to passengers were introduced _ Recently, DOT inspector general Kenneth Mead, at McCain's request, sent 20 examiners to airports to _ whether each airline is doing what it promised. Mead warns travelers shouldn't _ too much. Most of the promises are aimed at better communication with customers , not problems with flights . "Passengers should show more understanding to airlines about their _ to better air service." Spokeswoman Shelly Sassoon says. "And when _ are made, it takes a long time for them to be noticed," she says. Now, the efforts may be working. During the first quarter, Delta had the second-lowest rate of complaints among the _ 10 carriers. _ , its rate, along with other carriers', is up from last year.
